body_html:
I ran the tutorial (I disabled plotting because i didnt have a display):

python cifar10_tutorial.py
Files already downloaded and verified
Files already downloaded and verified
horse   cat   cat truck
epoch 1
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:       32720992     2660788    23783680       31308     6276524    29459632
Swap:      33460220           0    33460220
epoch 2
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:       32720992     2661224    23782668       31344     6277100    29458728
Swap:      33460220           0    33460220
epoch 3
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:       32720992     2661112    23782528       31272     6277352    29458632
Swap:      33460220           0    33460220

This is my output, memory seems rock-stable.
There are instances by the memory allocator used on the system where it keeps blocks around and doesn't free them. Maybe your default memory allocator keeps memory around?
Either that, or maybe plotting is adding unfreeable memory? Can you check by commenting out plotting? Comment out the line plt.imshow(np.transpose(npimg, (1, 2, 0)))

body:
I ran the tutorial (I disabled plotting because i didnt have a display):

```
python cifar10_tutorial.py
Files already downloaded and verified
Files already downloaded and verified
horse   cat   cat truck
epoch 1
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:       32720992     2660788    23783680       31308     6276524    29459632
Swap:      33460220           0    33460220
epoch 2
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:       32720992     2661224    23782668       31344     6277100    29458728
Swap:      33460220           0    33460220
epoch 3
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:       32720992     2661112    23782528       31272     6277352    29458632
Swap:      33460220           0    33460220
```

This is my output, memory seems rock-stable.
There are instances by the memory allocator used on the system where it keeps blocks around and doesn't free them. Maybe your default memory allocator keeps memory around?
Either that, or maybe plotting is adding unfreeable memory? Can you check by commenting out plotting? Comment out the line `plt.imshow(np.transpose(npimg, (1, 2, 0)))`
